awd_titl_txt: CPS: Breakthrough: Towards a Science of Attack Composition, Mitigation, and Verification in Cyber-Physical Systems: A Passivity-Based Framework
awd_abstract_narration:
This project focuses on modeling and mitigating cyber attacks on Cyber-Physical Systems (CPS), which are increasingly prevalent in all aspects of society such as health care, energy, and transportation.  Attacks initiated on the cyber components of CPS can be mounted remotely at little economic cost and can significantly degrade the safety and performance of CPS due to the tight coupling between cyber and physical components.  This project develops a passivity-based framework for modeling, composing, and mitigating multiple attacks on CPS.  Passivity is an energy dissipation property that provides basic rules for analyzing and composing interconnected systems.  In addition to passive adversary models and composition rules, this project will investigate techniques for decomposition of composed attack models into basic primitives which will lead to development of new mitigation strategies.  Approximate bi-simulation techniques will be introduced to verify the developed adversary models and mitigation strategies.  The proposed approach is general and will be applicable to mitigate CPS security challenges arising in multiple sectors including transportation, energy, manufacturing, and others.

The goals of the project are as follows: (a) research and development of passive dynamical models of multiple attacks, as well as characterization of the class of attacks that admit a passive representation; (b) investigation and development of passivity-based composition and decomposition rules, enabling identification of new attack variants and associated mitigation strategies; (c) research and development of approximate techniques for verification of composed adversary models and mitigation strategies; and (d) validation and prototyping of the proposed models through an experimental testbed.

por.por_cntn:
Project Overview: Cyber-physical systems (CPS) have become increasingly prevalent in areas such as health care, energy, and transportation as well as social networks and connected mobile devices. These systems have a tight coupling between cyber and physical components. Attacks to the cyber system can degrade the safety, availability, and performance of the physical components in the system. The cyber components can also introduce multiple attack entry points to the system, which make it easier for attacks to happen. In this project, we are specifically interested in ways to mitigate the propagation of computer malware, which poses a great threat to networked systems such as computer networks and CPS. Computer malware is an application that infects and installs itself onto a host computer and then uses the resources of the host to infect other devices on the network. Common attacks include denial of service, jamming, and spam. In addition, when multiple cyber-attacks occur simultaneously, a scientific approach is needed for modeling the attacks and developing effective mitigation strategies. Our three-year project contributed to this open research problem in the Science and Technology of CPS.

 

Intellectual Merit: Existing methods to mitigate malware attacks on CPS use a standard approach of periodically patching hosts against known malware. These methods incur costs due to the downtime during patching, delays due to packet filtering, and allocation of system resources towards decoy networks. Standard malware propagation models are based on epidemic dynamics which include uncertainties especially when multiple malware strains are propagating through the system. Our project developed a new approach to mitigating multiple malware viruses in a dynamical system based on passivity theory, which has to do with the energy in a system.  Our ?passivity-based? approach modeled the multi-virus propagation, patching, and filtering process as a passive dynamical system. We developed intuitive rules for updating the rate of packet inspection that guarantees the removal of the viruses in an economical way. Our key insight was to model the multi-virus propagation and the mitigation as a coupled dynamical system, which was passive. We showed the required patching rate is characterized by the ?passivity index? of the system. Our patching strategies were both static and adaptive. We also looked at both competing and co-existing malware in a system.

 

Broader Impact: Our research effort contributed to the basic science of CPS security. Our passivity-based modeling method will enhance the performance and security of CPS at the design stage. The passive dynamical systems models that we developed for the adversaries can be naturally integrated into existing models of CPS. Results of this project were integrated into an undergraduate cryptography course at UW ECE and presented at middle-school STEM outreach workshops. All of the work was disseminated to the NSF CPS community via peer-reviewed publications and the CPS-VO.
